comments.commentBody:
So the message is this: "Bernie Sanders [is] counting on a surge of new, irregular and independent voters to turn out in Iowa and propel [him] over rivals with greater support among traditional caucus voters[, but new voter registration has been slow, and] . . . it is hard to interpret the slow registration pace as anything other than reason to doubt a huge turnout."

But you follow with this: "It’s important to remember that the slow pace of voter registration does not preclude a high turnout on caucus day."

And then you reveal that "the Iowa caucuses this year occur [a month earlier than last year], and so the penultimate voter registration update of prior cycles would not have been affected by [the decline caused by] an annual voter status update [that occurs in January]."

I was not surprised that this is another "Sanders has no chance of winning; don't waste your vote on Sanders; vote for Clinton" piece from the NYT, but I didn't expect you to so transparently reveal the unreliability of the assumptions you are relying on in disparaging his campaign.

I don't know that Sanders (or Trump) needs a surge in registrations.  I think most people who are interested in voting are registered and most young people probably register when they get their driver's license (another commenter says you can register at the caucuses if so then this is even less important).  The issue is getting them to show up and vote/caucus.

Given the huge surge in voter engagement in in past cycles, wouldn't that mean less 'low hanging fruit' for registration in the past 4 years?  Remember, the Obama campaign predicted around 170,000 caucus participants, and there were 240,000.  After a surge like that, there are likely to be fewer non-registered participants available to sign up for the first time.  Similar issue on the Republican side, although smaller surge in 2012.

Once again mass media political pundits attempt to make a story out of the obvious. The fact there aren't any NEW Democratic voter registrations in Iowa means nothing in terms of the seismic shift in Democratic voter preferences which is the primary source of the surge in voter support for Sen. Sanders. Iowa has a closed primary for the  52 Democratic delegates meaning if registered as a Democrat you can vote only in the Democratic primary.

"The particularly low pace of Republican registration may suggest that the party’s high-profile contest hasn’t energized voters to the extent many imagined it would."

Maybe the 'energy' is counteracted by the nausea.

In Iowa, you have to get people to the caucus.  By reports and traditionally, this is where having an effective and comprehensive local organization comes into play.  Iowa's a big state and there are more than a thousand caucus sites.  According to reporting, Mr. Trump's campaign has five people working the state.

10,000 new vters and and even a smaller part of this group of these few have such a big bite about who will be the leader of the free world??
Smke filled rooms while just a few had more brain power than the whole of Iowa. .

Bernie supporter: Yeah, it's time for a political revolution!!!

Pollster: So are you going to vote?

Bernie supporter: Nah, I have a paper due.

Gotta have a new column about something every day -- more daffodils flowering in Iowa, baseball caps with T on it more common on playgrounds.
Why not wait until after the Iowa caucuses when we'll know something?

replies.commentBody: The problem for the parties is, of course, that people might just register for the OTHER party.  I don't think that any jurisdiction in the country allows a voter registration drive that only registers voters for one party.  Explains the GOP's efforts in many some states to purge voter rolls and restrict voter registration.
Most political consultants are paid a percentage of the money they spend on advertising, so it's in their self interest to spend big bucks on ads.

comments.commentBody: I always wonder why political campaigns keep on spending money on highly paid consultants and strategists, as well as expensive TV ads, instead of putting money in getting people to register.  Better results could be got if instead they hired young volunteers, paying them a doable salary, to take charge of an assigned district and making sure, after canvassing, to get people to register, providing help and transportation if needed.

I think there are plenty of other factors that will determine who wins the caucus besides a percentage of new voters.  Trump may have an easier time since there are so many candidates on the GOP side.  For Sanders it will be  a tougher  ride but not impossible to either win the caucus outright , or finish very strong.  Personally, I would like to see O'Malley surge and make a strong showing so he would stop being overlooked by the media. So much press goes to Sanders and Clinton we forget there is another option.  That is what democracy is all about. Options, choices.

replies.commentBody:
Nate explicitly addresses that point towards the end.

"Most of the increase in turnout for Mr. Obama came from voters who were already registered but hadn’t previously participated in the caucus, not from people who had not yet registered to vote."

Sanders real problem is that his unregistered supporters are likely to be college students. Classes are in session this time so students will be clustered in a comparative handful of college precincts instead of all over the state which will blunt their impact.

The data suggests that Obama's win came less from first timers registering to vote at the caucus and more from those who'd registered before but hadn't previously participated in the caucus (which points to Obama's success in increasing turn-out).

This article is simply saying that the number of people registering for the first time is lower than that of 2008 (which could make a Sanders win difficult) or 2012 (which might make a Trump win difficult) which may - or may not - affect how many turn-out to caucus.

comments.commentBody: In Iowa, an individual can register at the caucus. In 2008, the surge in voter registration took place at the caucus and afterward.
